这是我在Steam上通关的第一款游戏，理应为他写几句评价。
我是预购的豪华版，2024年9月底来到了大石敢当面前，没想到完成一周目居然就到了2025年12月7号。
作为动作游戏苦手，很多boss是靠轮椅打法过的，但当我再一次击败大圣残躯，耳边响起《云宫迅音》，那份感动真的无与伦比。

当金箍棒的嗡鸣穿透屏幕，当花果山的残阳映红眼底，《黑神话：悟空》从来都不只是一款游戏。它是一场跨越童年与成年的对话，一次对东方神话的深情叩问，更是将我们心底沉睡多年的英雄梦，连同那些未被驯服的反抗欲，一并唤醒的精神盛宴。
神话祛魅：在黑暗里看见真实的人性
我们自幼熟记的西游，是神佛庇佑的光明叙事，而《黑神话》却敢撕开神话的华美外衣，露出底下权力的褶皱与人性的斑驳。天庭不再是正义的化身，而是用 “天命” 编织枷锁的权力机器；神佛并非慈悲为怀，反倒借着 “普渡众生” 的名义，吞噬着众生的信仰与自由。
这里的每一个角色，都带着沉甸甸的烟火气与悲剧感。八戒憨态可掬地跟在身后，一遍遍复述着与猴哥的过往，那些未曾说出口的思念，藏着中国人最含蓄的兄弟情；菩提祖师的壁画前，飘落的菩提叶默默回血，那句 “我有一个故人，怕他闯下烧身大祸”，道尽了师父对弟子藏于心底的牵挂与庇佑；通臂猿猴踏遍三界寻找五蕴，只为再见 “孩子” 一面，当看到身着大圣铠甲的天命人时，她眼中的执念化为释然，让人心碎又温暖。就连悟空本人，也不再是无所不能的齐天大圣。他是在神性与兽性间挣扎的反英雄，是识破神佛骗局后以死反抗的觉醒者，是即便肉身覆灭，意志也依然要冲破轮回的孤勇者。这些破碎的、不完美的形象，恰恰戳中了我们内心最柔软的地方 —— 我们都曾渴望成为英雄，却也都明白，真正的勇敢，是认清世界的荒诞后，依然选择坚守本心。
意志永生：反抗是刻在骨子里的基因
游戏最动人的内核，从来不是惊天动地的 BOSS 战，而是对 “自由” 与 “反抗” 的永恒歌颂。金箍不再是简单的法器，而是体制的规训、命运的枷锁；取经路也不是通往救赎的坦途，而是一场被操控的轮回骗局。
天命人的每一次死亡与重生，都是对既定命运的反抗；每一次拒绝戴上金箍的选择，都是对自由意志的坚守。当最终在花果山的残阳下，《云宫迅音》的旋律缓缓响起，我们穿上凤翅紫金冠、锁子黄金甲，握住那根沉甸甸的金箍棒时，心中涌起的早已不是单纯的激动，而是一种成年后久违的、梦想成真的震颤。
我们终于可以不再只是旁观者，而是成为了那个从小就向往的英雄 —— 不是被神佛驯服的 “斗战胜佛”，而是永远敢于挑战权威、打破枷锁的 “齐天大圣”。这种感动，源于文化血脉的共鸣，更源于我们每个人都曾有过的、不愿被世俗磨平棱角的倔强。
文化回响：在第九艺术里安放民族的乡愁
对于我们这代人而言，《西游记》是刻在 DNA 里的文化记忆。而《黑神话》最了不起的地方，是用次世代技术，将那些只存在于文字与想象中的东方美学，具象成了可触可感的沉浸式体验。千佛古刹的残破佛像、悬空寺的飞檐斗拱、水墨写意与粒子特效交织的战斗场景，每一处都透着熟悉的东方韵味。
当外国玩家在惊叹神话的瑰丽时，我们感受到的，是一种文化自信的回归。我们终于不用再在西方游戏里扮演牛仔、刺客，而是可以回到自己的文化土壤，扮演那个从小就扎根在心底的英雄。这种归属感，是任何外来作品都无法给予的，它像一杯陈酿，越品越浓，越品越让人动容。
《黑神话：悟空》的成功，从来不止于技术的突破，更在于它让我们重新审视自己的文化，重新拥抱心底的英雄梦。它告诉我们，神话从未远去，那些关于反抗、关于坚守、关于情谊的故事，始终在我们的血脉里流淌；它也让我们明白，真正的自由，不是颠覆一切，而是在认清生活的真相后，依然保有那份不被驯服的勇气。

①美术设计：10.0分。这没什么好说的，满分实至名归。亮眼之处在于每章动画、每章画卷、地图中现实古迹的编排。
②剧情设计：9.0分。此处在网上争议极大，是非曲直，实难以论说，只能斗胆跟评两句。第一章主题是观音妙评；第二章主题是秩序尊卑由天定，这也是中国历史上经久不衰的哲学议题；第三章主题是人心是试探不得的；第四章主题是相爱不一定要在一起；第五章主题是中老年人的身不由己，此点个人感触很深，进入社会之后个人努力确实对事情结果的占比在逐渐下降；第六章主题则是各种意义上的未竟。首先，各章主题分明，很好的阐述了人性中爱与复仇两大核心。其次，各章主题很符合中国传统文学“劝世教人”的核心主旨，章回体结构和半白半文的语言，加上第九艺术的表现力，可以说，黑神话悟空确实是尊重了原著。若就此点论之，各角色人物形象已然不重要，因为后者是具有时代性的，也是历代层垒叠加的结果。综合以上两点，在崇尚个人自由和物质生活从而导致精神生活出现虚无主义倾向的当代，悟空的剧情确实存在一定的教育意义。但是剧情也有问题，即存在一定程度的“中皮西骨”现象。中国传统文学并不主张绝对的善恶，一切权力关系均存在内外两因，套用剧情中的话就是“你那大师兄其实并不圆满”，而不是西方式for freedom的二元对立论。漫天神佛对灵韵的系统性剥削一定是建立在一个不得不的理由之上，否则一个绝对剥削的政治体制绝对难以维持，此处黑神话并没有详加阐述，希望在dlc中游科有所解答。综之，剧情处我个人给9.0分。
③音乐设计：10分。此处分为三块，一是每章主题音乐。不论是《看见》的娓娓道来，还是《三界四洲》的欲壑难填，亦或是《勿听》的百转千回，还是《不由己》的歇斯底里，亦或是《未竟》的饱经沧桑都令人印象深刻。二是游戏背景音乐，首推自然是《敢问路在何方》变调，百转千回，余音绕柱，把“斗罢艰险又出发”展现的淋漓尽致。其他背景音乐也很不错，主要表现在营造战斗氛围的同时还做到了不喧宾夺主。其他同类作品常有boss战多次挑战，导致催人奋进的背景乐变成了无情嘲讽的事实，但黑神话可以说完美避开了这一点。第三块是音效。此处主要指地图背景音效，正如b站up老李聊点什么所说，背景音效真正做到了“大音希声”，即在小雷音寺有寺庙的感觉，在黄花观有道观的感觉。而且现实的背景音效是非常复杂的，有动物声、有风声、有人声，通过音效营造一个真实的环境是很困难的，游科在此处一定是下了极大的功夫。其次是打击音效，此处我个人感觉没什么雷点，但也说不出好赖，就不评价了。
④地图设计：8.5分。其中第一章9.5分，游科在设计小规模的箱庭场景上表现不错。第二章9.0分。第三章8.0分，极乐谷差点给人干出雪盲症。第四章8.0分，阴间下洞。第五章8.0分。第六章5.5分，史中史。综合评价，8.5分。黑神话地图设计中网上最具争议的是便是空气墙，这个问题我个人认为在第二章体现最明显，其出现的根本原因还是黑神话美术太真实，导致在探图时经常出现“我认为此地能去，但是被空气墙阻挡”的情况，此种“为了艺术效果牺牲游戏性”的选择因人而异，不论褒贬皆无可指摘。所有地图中设计最出色的是浮屠塔，如果真的存在十八层地狱，那一定就是浮屠塔的样子。其中石质的转经塔旋转的声音如同磨盘一样在我心中研磨，很有一种身处旋涡无法自拔的无力感，暗合小张太子的“规劝”。加上背景乐中令人牙酸的野兽嘶吼和时不时偷袭的野怪还有几分钟一次的红眼，以及螺旋阶梯的设计，氛围感真的拉满，反正我个人当时被吓得不轻，只想快点逃离。不过一层到四层光线转明以及视野逐渐开阔，确实有柳岸明花的幸存感。另外，此处可以看到游科对于黑神话的设计是非常极端的，他们在商业和价值输出的取舍中偏向了后者，以至于游戏处处体现出了近乎神经质般的偏执。我猜测游科当时的想法就是，这可能是各种意义上第一次也是最后一次说自己想说的机会，不如抓住机会一股脑的全说了，哪怕存在明显工期不足导致的赶工，也要把故事输出出来。
⑤动作设计，9.0分。此处无法详评，因为我对于此处没有什么研究，只能说对我来说没有雷点。不过有一点感受，除了劈棍戳棍和立棍，是不是还缺了一个扫棍之类的对群攻击棍法，总有一种没做完的感觉。还有经过解析，二郎神有70+的变招种类，大圣残躯有40+的变招种类，可以说量堆的相当足，甚至可以说有一点量变引起质变的味道。
⑥人物形象塑造，9.5分。总体而言，各个人物的形象塑造皆很饱满，其中最喜欢的还是大圣，虽然处处没有大圣，但是处处皆是大圣。影神图、章回画卷、游戏其他角色口述各种叙述有真有假，有古有今，真正体现出了老猴所说“你那大师兄并不圆满”。

剧情看似宏大，但是你不出DLC也不出序章，那就是一群中二病，只会说屁用没有，画大饼式剧情。
一共玩了93个小时，这贯穿全局一成不变怪物就这几个招式仿佛复制黏贴，boss战仿佛是为了下一个boss战而生的，打完只有结束后的解脱，然后马上打下一个小boss,重复的boss战斗使其更累而不是更刺激，打小怪基本没有收益，甚至也没有其他娱乐的收益，没有任何有意义的探索。

刚发售就买了，特地等到热度过了来玩，耗时57小时成功通关， 一开始看到预告片的时候，我本来并不觉得这游戏能达到我的预期，特别是听到身边人都在讨论‘‘一个没有任何游戏开发经验的公司要做大型买断制单机游戏’’这在中国根本不可能，因为连731这样的题材都能拿来赚钱，我根本不会承认会有这样的一款游戏出现，太不真实了 现在不得不承认这是一款用心的好游戏 每个boss都让我酣畅淋漓，扣人心弦的故事总会让我好奇后续的内容，每一个刻画鲜美的角色都能让我共情，二郎神我花了半小时研究不同打法使劲浑身解数才过的，看到结尾制作名单更是怅然若失恍惚了好久，很久没有这么认真的评价一款游戏了 凌晨6点我还不睡特地来给黑猴打好评， 夯爆了哥们 这个游戏给我留下了很深的印象 我应该会记很久

黑猴这游戏，我玩的时间越长，就越是觉得，其最大的缺点，就是一周目的时候，玩家一旦卡在某个BOSS那里，就会卡上好久。像我总是打不过晦月魔君，死了上百次，这个挫败感实在是太强了！以至于我有一个多月都不想玩。游科为什么不在一周目让玩家体验故事模式，就所有BOSS打起来都比现有一周目的难度更简单。先让玩家把剧情连贯流畅的完整体验一遍，到了二周目再逐渐变难也行啊。就非要在一周目，角色各项数值都不高的时候，用BOSS卡住玩家，然后卡得时间长了，挫败感太强，失去了热情，就不想玩了。

就哪怕故事写得再好，玩家打不过BOSS，卡住了。或者就算打过了，可以继续体验剧情了，之前发生了什么都已经忘了。剧情写得那么好，一周目就没有一个流畅连贯的体验，又有什么用呢？

入坑的第一款游戏，美术风格太好了，纯中式，没有任何西幻风，这很难做到，我记得之前看到个视频，有个up主自己做了一个山海经主题的视频，但是里面全都是蜥蜴龙或者克苏鲁类型的怪，但是黑猴完全没有这总感觉，主美上大分，还有配音做的也特别特别好，没有违和感，这在很多游戏都做不到，甚至是我更喜欢的影之刃零，美术和配音都还是比不上黑猴。就是游戏时长太少了，而且比较枯燥，打完一周目就没有动力了，希望后续的新作打磨得更精致一些
恶心玩意，狗屎第六章，你在大石敢当上面放个土地庙会死吗？打他不是闪退就是突然卡住，血条直接不见了，卡在原地，打也打不了，重新传送，跑过来又是满血。这些还只是其中之一，各种各样的恶心事，打到第六章了是真的忍不了了，9700x，48g内存，5060不配玩你贵游？一年多了你还跟我说你没时间优化？

文化内核深厚：游戏以中国传统神话《西游记》为背景，挖掘了原著中更为黑暗、复杂的一面，神佛并非全然慈悲，妖魔鬼怪也有自己的苦衷与执念，构建了一个充满阴谋论色彩的西游世界。同时，游戏中充满了对 “天命”“因果”“修行” 等中国传统哲学概念的探讨，让游戏超越了单纯的打怪升级，有了更深的思辨空间。
画面美术惊艳：利用虚幻引擎 5 的强大性能，游戏呈现出了令人惊叹的视觉效果。从古刹残垣、雪岭荒原，到盘丝洞府的诡谲、紫云山的奇崛，每一处场景都极致还原了中式古典美学中的意境。游戏中的角色、建筑、器物、服饰都有着深厚的考据，能在中国古代雕塑、壁画和建筑中找到原型，充满了文化的 “质感”。
战斗系统出色：战斗系统以 “金箍棒” 为核心，劈、戳、砸、立等棍术招式手感扎实，音效反馈出色，完美体现了 “重器” 的力量感。同时，将 “七十二变” 巧妙地融入战斗系统，玩家通过积累 “识破” 值，可以变身成特定的妖怪，使用其特殊技能进行战斗，增加了战斗的多样性和策略深度。此外，定身术、毫毛分身等经典法术的加入，也让战斗充满了变化。
BOSS 设计精彩：游戏中的 BOSS 设计独特，如寅虎的攻击欲望强，技能帅气，交互性好，让玩家感受到了东方武术的魅力。虎先锋等 BOSS 的设计也很成功，有参与感和代入感，能和玩家打的有来有回。虽然部分 BOSS 难度较高，但玩家通过不断尝试和学习，能够逐渐掌握其攻击模式和应对策略，打败 BOSS 后能获得强烈的成就感。
难度把控得当：游戏没有难度选择，但难度把控在一个较为完美的临界点，既没有像魂游那么难，也没有像 ARPG 爽游那么无脑，对于动作游戏老手比较友善，新手玩家通过不断练习和合理利用支线获取的物品等也能够顺利通关，给所有玩家都能带来良好的游戏体验。
缺点
地图引导不足：游戏没有明确的指引，没有地图中的地标建筑，甚至连小地图和方位指示器都没有，玩家在探索时容易迷路，尤其是在第二章，玩家可能会在来回迷路刷怪中花费数小时，影响了游戏的流畅度和沉浸感。
部分系统存在问题：游戏中的嗑药与喝酒操作有时不够稳定，存在有时候吃不了药，有时候连嗑两粒的情况。此外，某些物品的掉落率较低，玩家可能需要花费大量时间刷取，影响了游戏体验。字幕大小不能调节，对于部分玩家来说可能不太友好。
后期关卡设计欠佳：部分玩家认为游戏后面三章在关卡设计和剧情引导上与前三章有不小差距。第四章白眼作为关底 BOSS 在剧情上略显突兀，第五章的一条路走到底的设计缺少游戏的沉浸感，第六章也存在一些问题，影响了游戏的整体质量。
112小时的游戏时长停留在屏幕上，我终于敢说自己触碰到了这款国产3A的全貌——它不止是一场酣畅的动作盛宴，更是一次穿越神话迷雾的修行，有震撼到失语的高光，也有瑕不掩瑜的遗憾，却终究用东方风骨，撑起了玩家对国产3A的所有期待。

满足了小时候的幻想，把志怪神话，妖魔鬼怪具象化了，多少文化，古迹通过游戏的方式呈现出来，具有里程碑式的意义，游科确实没有辜负我的期待。

优点太多了，我就挑几个比较戳我的吧
1.怪物的种类多的眼花缭乱，爱不释手，建模也很细。
2.识破，铜头反震，还有四段棍式，是真的很爽。最后大圣残躯的几个彩蛋设计，简直绝了。
3.过场动画很好看，故事情节很丰满，碎片化叙事，但没有黑魂那么碎，那么隐晦，也可能是有文化基础的原因。
4.顶级的配乐把神话的氛围衬托的恰到好处，配音贴合完全不出戏，音效除了打击感方面好像有点小瑕疵，基本完美。
5.妖怪图鉴的故事太丰富了，文化底蕴是真厚实。

缺点呢我比较在意的
1.空气墙，老生常谈了，也不算大毛病，熟悉之后再加上地图，问题不大。
2.普通第四段感觉有点墨迹，和花里胡哨的感觉。
3.晦月魔君，亢金龙，白眼魔君，这些粪怪打的太难受了，反例就是毒敌大王，虽然难，但是很爽。
4.没有QTE，比较可惜。
5.花果山做得有点草率了

还有特别想说的一点，游科确实交上了一份很完美的答卷，也值得我们期待，但没比必要把它神化，捧上神坛，产生没必要的“皈依者狂热”。好就夸，不好就要骂，千万别把饭圈那一套带进来，党同伐异，容不得半点负面评论，这样对游科，对喜欢游戏的你我，对国产游戏都不是什么好事。
最后，对于《钟馗》的项目我表示不理解，并不是不相信游科能把《钟馗》做好，而是担心步子太大容易扯到蛋，还有黑神话后续破灭的残念，恐怕《黑猴》的后续弄不好得2030年以后了。（话说是不是因为这些年开发黑猴，游科人对这些素材都有点恶心了，想换换心情？）
很好玩，游戏刚出来就想买了，可惜当时没有电脑，感觉买了用不上。现在玩起来也是很舒服，也有朋友在教我玩，得心应手。

以我个人观点来说，黑神话悟空如果满分十分我打七分：
首先一分扣在战斗系统的深度上，一个主打动作以及boss战的rpg游戏，主角从头到尾只有戳劈立三种招式，武器也没有什么变化，加点并没有对招数动作进行大的改变，更像是招数附加了额外功能，而法宝、法术、妖怪精魄这些设计也仅仅浅尝辄止没有更深层的搭配，这使得游戏后期战斗略显无聊。
第二分扣在地图设计以及引导上，这块儿就不多说了，满地的空气墙加上没有地图，让跑图简直像一种折磨，你视觉上能过去而实际上只能在一条宽阔的道路前面走太空步，多少有点让人失望。
第三分扣在中后期内容太空，我打完前两章觉得这个剧情内容方面都很扎实，但越到后面越觉得内容贫乏，很多时候就单给你个大地图稀拉拉的放几只怪，前后反差太大让人有点难以接受。
还有剧情上有点十几年前阴谋论黑深残那味儿，不过人都叫黑神话了也没什么好说的

作为游戏科学的第一部作品，同时也是中国3A游戏的开山之作，整体质量优秀得令人惊讶。《黑神话》并非完美的游戏，但足以在一众顶级3A中“上桌吃饭”，角逐GOTY更是可以说给中国3A游戏起了一个非常高的调子，其无疑将成为未来很长时间内国产3A前路上的高山。花果山地图的半成品形态是整部游戏最大的缺憾，但剧情、音乐、（以空气墙为代价换来的）美术、打斗系统设计、战斗演出等其他方面都呈现出顶级3A的形态，整体瑕不掩瑜，单论游戏质量可以打到4/5，而游戏过程中常常出现的“这是以我的母语创造的游戏”“这是我的民族的文化产品”的想法让我的游玩体验更上一层楼，因此打到4.5/5。总的来说，《黑神话》远远超出了我的预期，是我心中的GOTY。

这款游戏作为国人的第一款3A游戏，以及我接触过的第一款3A游戏，给我带来的第一印象是很不错的。取材来自于大家熟悉的西游记，不过不同的是大圣在故事里陨落了。关于美术质量，从开局CG到最后一战，场景的刻画是非常精良的。该说不说前面两章连小怪都会有一些特殊的台词。可能因为游戏赶工期这些小细节在后面的章节没有体现。

说到剧情，玩家将扮演天命人一路上消灭妖王，寻找大圣的六根的故事。原本的结局应该是天命人继承大圣的意志并且戴上了金箍。但是当玩家做完所有章节的支线任务，并且与二郎神交战后，我们才意识到并不像序章那样大圣被二郎神杀死了，而是主动寻死。随着天命人同样历经九九八十一难后，我们也能逐渐发现天庭黑暗的一面。并且在最后战胜大圣残躯后拒绝带上金箍。其实有一个细节是，如果触发的是坏结局的话，石猿会复原并且老猴子会开始寻找下一个天命人。我认为在编剧上无论是细节还是内容的精彩程度斗非常完美了，无论是对原著的复刻以及自己的创新。

关于游戏玩法，不同于魂类游戏，这个游戏有丰富的技能系统，这样能更容易被大众接受，以至于玩家不是为了针对每个不同行为的boss去背出招或者通过反复练习去掌握不同的棍法流派。在难度上，因为有等级系统，以及丹药系统，卡关的事情会比较少发生。作为一个中等水平的动作游戏玩家，对于一些网传公认很难的boss虎先锋，小黄龙，二郎神。我最多花了40多次去战胜它们。虽然说玩的过程中有点红温，但是总体来说负反馈没那么大。我在游玩过程中有2次动过开修改器的想法，不过后来还是通过努力练习打败了困难的boss。

美中不足的是这个游戏还是存在一些优化问题。在最后一张抓凤翅将军的时候，游戏有可能会闪退。在第二章隐藏关沙漠以及第三关的部分雪地渲染会非常奇怪。 在挑战部分能飞天的boss的时候hitbox会很奇怪，很多时候莫名其妙打不中。这些有待优化。

总体来说黑神话悟空是一款非常优秀的3A游戏，我相信也为中国3A大作开了个好头！非常推荐这款游戏！！

情怀什么的也不提了，大伙提的很多了，这种游戏就得咱们自己人做啊。说说游戏本身，这游戏不是魂游，硬要说我觉得像战神＋仁王＋魂的结合（没什么不好的）。游戏画面和音乐顶中顶，战斗手感就很爽，记得去年和我舍友刚开始玩这游戏的时候，我对黑猴的评价是：游玩过程中根本感受不到是国产游戏。这不是贬义啊，这游戏中国文化很多、也很优秀，但是对当时的我来说，国产能产出这种质量的游戏想都不敢想，现在可能大伙感知不大了，当时真给震撼到了。扯得有点远，虽然很多人说黑猴是类战神，但游玩过程绝对比战神有意思的，战神后面重复的解密太多了，真有点乏了，黑猴就不一样，这游戏模式有点像bossrush，一个头目接一个头目，中间也会给你休息的节奏，个人认为这种节奏把控很得当。游戏场景、剧情、章节动画等等真狠狠文化输出了，玩中国文化为题材的游戏感觉还是不一样啊（是不是说不提情怀来着。。。）
说说不足，首先是后两章的完成度确实欠佳了，能看出赶工了，花果山坐筋斗云是很爽，但我有很长时间都是瞎逛，不看攻略很多地方找不到，而且第六章boss也不多。如果你是魂游玩家，建议玩这游戏抛弃掉之前的战斗思路，黑猴的战斗思路有点类似仁王，鼓励你去进攻，这点从游戏战斗系统中无格挡也能看出来。动作系统不错，个人比较喜欢劈和戳，立棍没有类似识破和退寸的系统，基本只用来打蓄力重击了。三种架势蛮有意思，但感觉拓展的宽度和深度不是很够，和仁王这种比动作系统深度还是有差距的，黑猴和仁王动作系统的差距大概就像仁王和黑猴美术上的差距了（其实动作系统深度不深某种意义也不是坏事，仁王那种一下给你塞太多系统很容易劝退玩家）。另外这游戏的索敌系统面对一些飞天怪很难受，视角不知道给你锁哪去了，画面信息一下很有限（或者说看不到理应能看到的重点），这点希望之后能改善。还有这游戏黑的地方真的很黑，啥都看不见，可能是ue5光照引擎的问题吧，这问题也挺难受的。
总结下这游戏，就算抛开情怀不提也能打9/10分，加上情怀那就更别说了。瑕不掩瑜的优秀大作。

推荐入手的国产3A游戏，游戏的打击感和演出效果都是极好。全成就之后再来追评的，难度较低，我记得是速通二周目即可白金，就是会有一些材料可能刷的比较心累，概率掉落这种。要说印象最深的BOSS的话，一个是幽魂，一个虎先锋，一个杨戬，这几个boss设置的难度偏高但打起来又极具交互感和反馈感，幽魂是初见杀比较难受，后面打则简单了很多。粪怪的话我记得有小黄龙和青背龙，第一个多动症+高伤害，对出手时机要求极高。第二个纯数值怪。
[hr][/hr]这游戏也并非没有缺点，首先是一些地方的空气墙，缺乏地图探索的乐趣。其次，人物的动作并不连贯，会有一种比较奇怪的停顿感，可能是为了动作演出的完整性，但是我刚开始适应则比较难受。最后是游戏的最后2章的赶工和游戏整体剧情问题，最后的部分感觉略微粗糙且剧情薄弱。
[hr][/hr]总结下来，这个游戏是一款非常优秀的3A游戏，打击感和演出效果都是一流，但，过多的流量曝光和热度也让我拉高了对它的期待，总觉得它缺了点非常拔尖的特点，期待游戏科学后续的作品。

首先地图设计是狗屎，从拾取奖励到支线的安排上都是鼓励探索的设计，然后一坨的地图设计和到处都是的空气墙又完美的抑制了玩家探索的欲望。往往玩家从一开始兴致勃勃的找地图上没探索过的区域，然后先是发现到处做的都一样，分不清哪里来过哪里没来；然后好不容易发现一处疑似是隐藏道路的地方，冲过去发现是空气墙走不了。你设计时候要是暂时不想让玩家探索你就放个门不能从这一侧打开，你要是永远不想让玩家进来你就应该用石头把路堵上或者放上悬崖，而不是像现在这样看起来能走其实有空气墙。
然后战斗系统说狗屎有些过分，但是只是有部分场次的战斗达到了不错的水平，有些战斗说是狗屎都是在侮辱狗屎。不说棍子的操作手感。装备只能迭代而不能升级，造成有些战斗中明明有更适合这次战斗的装备效果，但是因为是前期装备数值的不足，导致只能穿护甲足而效果没卵用的装备，有小孩穿大人衣服的感觉。怪物的动作不知道实际是怎样设计的，但我玩起来是没用rng的，如果你的动作一定，那boss的反应也是一定的，导致同一个boss的打法十分僵化，重复游玩的体验性也不足。然后第二章的石头纯屎，不知道是不是设计时候想要腾云驾雾去打然后发现做不出来，最后只能草草结尾；第三章的龙打起来体验更是像便秘，一直在重复这样的过程：boss在远处消耗你，你冲过去，boss打你一下然后离你又变的很远，你冲过去了之后boss开始盘旋，你a了半天打不动boss，boss喷你一口然后又拉开距离然后重复；你要是说黄风的是利用了黄沙迷惑你让你视角锁不住，那这个龙你也没法解释为什么视角绕绕绕去。最后探索欲望又没有，导致第一张避火罩第二章定风丹都是打完boss也来不及发现，大大弱化了boss章的体验，给人感觉boss就是肉一点的小怪。

《黑神话：悟空》全面测评
 
游戏基本概况

游戏名称：黑神话：悟空 (Black Myth: Wukong)
开发商：游戏科学(Game Science)
发行日期：2024年8月20日
平台：PC/PS5/Xbox Series X|S
类型：第三人称动作角色扮演(ARPG)，类魂游戏风格
评分：IGN中国10/10，IGN全球8/10，Metacritic 83分(PC版)，Steam 96%好评
 
核心体验测评
 
1. 视觉表现：★★★★★
 
- 画质：UE5引擎打造，照片级写实，光影与材质细节令人惊叹，被数毛社评为"近年来最佳视觉效果之一"
- 美术风格：融合中国传统水墨与写实主义，场景设计如同"动态东方画卷"，怪物与BOSS设计独特且富有想象力
- 技术优化：PC版支持DLSS 4.0/XeSS 2.0/FSR 4.0，RTX 5090可达240+帧；PS5原生4K/60帧稳定运行
 
2. 战斗系统：★★★★★
 
- 棍法系统：三种形态(劈棍、戳棍、扫棍)，每种风格对应不同战术，打击感扎实厚重，反馈清晰
- 技能体系：
- 法术(定身术、火眼金睛等)：可打断BOSS技能或探索辅助
- 变身系统：五十四种精魄变身，每种赋予独特能力(如化身为虎增强近战)
- 武器与披挂：十余种属性棍棒，搭配不同披挂创造多样战斗风格 
- BOSS战：80+首领战，设计精妙，挑战性强，部分被玩家称为"爽到飞起"的体验，尤其是与传统神话角色(杨戬、西王母等)的对决
 
3. 剧情与世界观：★★★★☆
 
- 故事：重构西游神话，讲述"天命人"寻找真相的旅程，穿插悟空与二郎神的"500年赌约"，结局分"坏结局"与"好结局"
- 叙事：多线叙事，支线任务与隐藏剧情丰富，通过"神影图"(图鉴)和NPC对话揭示深层故事
- 文化呈现：深度融合《西游记》元素，配乐采用《云宫迅音》等经典曲目，营造浓厚中国古典氛围
 
4. 探索与关卡：★★★★☆
 
- 地图设计：非线性探索，隐藏路径与秘密丰富，但部分区域存在"空气墙"影响体验 
- 环境细节：每个区域主题鲜明，细节考究，如黑风山、花果山等场景还原度高
- 收集要素：大量隐藏道具、丹药配方、变身精魄，全收集需约100小时
 
5. 音效与音乐：★★★★★
 
- 配乐：中国古典乐器+现代编曲，与场景完美契合，IGN评价"过耳不忘"
- 音效：金箍棒打击、法术释放、怪物嘶吼等音效设计极具代入感，增强战斗体验
 
游戏优缺点分析
 
优点：
 
1. 世界级美术与技术：画面表现达到国际3A水准，成为国产游戏标杆
2. 深度战斗系统：棍法+法术+变身组合，策略性与操作感兼备，媲美《艾尔登法环》
3. Boss战设计：规模与创意俱佳，部分战斗堪称"艺术品"，挑战性与成就感平衡
4. 文化传承创新：重构西游故事，既保留传统精神又赋予现代叙事
 
缺点：
 
1. 技术问题：初期存在闪退、穿模、语言切换等Bug(已通过更新修复大部分)
2. 探索体验：空气墙过多限制探索自由度，部分地图设计较空 
3. 剧情争议：部分玩家认为叙事节奏欠佳，结局设计不够圆满
4. 难度门槛：无难度选择(更新后已添加)，对新手不够友好
 
总体评价：★★★★★
 
《黑神话：悟空》是国产游戏里程碑式作品，以三分之一国际3A团队规模，创造出足以与全球顶级作品比肩的游戏体验。IGN中国评价："说这是一场工业奇迹也绝不为过"。
 
适合人群：
 
- 动作游戏爱好者(尤其是类魂游戏粉丝)
- 西游记文化爱好者
- 追求高品质游戏体验的玩家
- 支持国产游戏发展的玩家
 
不适合：休闲玩家、对高难度游戏有抵触的玩家
 
最新动态：
 
**DLC"大闹天宫"**已于2025年推出，获MC 93高分，新增"九环锡杖"武器、新Boss与剧情，延续本体高品质。官方确认后续还将开发"狮驼岭"和"女儿国"主题DLC。
 
最后在总结一下：
 
《黑神话：悟空》不仅是一款优秀的游戏，更是中国游戏产业崛起的标志。它证明了中国团队有能力制作出具有全球竞争力的3A大作，为国产游戏树立了新标杆。如果你是动作游戏爱好者，这款作品绝对不容错过。
 
注：本评测基于2025年12月最新版本(含DLC)，游戏仍在持续更新优化中。

2024年8月预购，2025年12月25日晚通关。为什么花了这么长时间，是因为我在黑猴之前玩法环复健，黑猴浅尝之后，想先把法环通了（这两个游戏的操作和逻辑南辕北辙）。但是沟槽的法环花了我150个小时（这个游戏哪都好，唯一的缺点是容量太大了。为什么有执念，见我的另一篇评测）。之后还白金了只狼、黄油猫，才捡回了黑猴。好在热潮已褪去，可以心平气和地慢慢体会这个国产神作。
#画面：10/10，业界里程碑，花了大心思。每一个BOSS的美术和动作都是溢出的（除了第六章石敢当），好评。回想起看最后一个预告片MV时，打斗场面如跑马灯般应接不暇，当时都惊了，第一作游戏体量就这么大。整体资源量感觉是大于魂3本体的，很多美术资源都是一次性的，没有复用很可惜。
#剧情：10/10，不得不说基于国产名著所衍生的剧情，深度超乎想象。西游记本身就是明代官场的隐喻之作，本作更是将原著中人世炎凉、人心难测的基调完美继承，有无社会阅历都能在其中得到别样的滋味。加之中文语境下极大降低了理解难度，全程都是享受。看完牛魔王那章结尾动画，心情久久不能平息，甚至无心关注结局是什么故事，只想去机核找找老牛的深度解读，尝试读懂这个中年故事。（与之相比，魂系的所谓深度剧情，其实看穿了后很单薄）
#游玩机制：3/10，如果这个游戏是我的第一款游戏，我可能会觉得动作很优秀爽快，BOSS设计十分优秀。可惜我玩过了魂游和只狼，觉得还是有硬伤。动作模组单一缺乏变体，最大的问题是刮痧、缺乏正向反馈（缺乏处决一类的机制）（缺乏一种我和高手过招心砰砰直跳的感觉，轮到我出招也只能刮痧，只有疲惫），打到虎先锋的时候已经红温了，一怒之下开了风灵月影，升了50级、开无限葫芦，游戏终于能玩了起来。对，难度曲线的设计也有问题，地图关卡的设计也缺乏亮点（空气墙就不赘述了），升级加点非常不直观。
#音乐、MV：10/10，机核专访节目中了解到，冯骥创办这个公司就是为了给他写歌词用的，此言不虚。游戏真正想传达的价值观，其实都在歌词里。结合之前说剧情的突出表现，二者很好地互相结合，实现了1+1>2的效果。不说了，去B站再听一遍音乐会。（PS，不堕轮回万古传，歌里还有冯骥的意识形态表达，在此不表，瑞斯拜）
#总结：总而言之，是一部瑕不掩瑜之作。于我个人而言，是一部治好我电子ED的佳作，让我捡起了中断两年的法环并白金、让我鼓起勇气挑战难关，这部游戏的价值就不可估量。于我们的生活而言，我的父母都要慕名来看一眼“这就是黑神话”，游戏被主流社会逐渐接受、成为一件上台面的事情，白广大、Felania老师们主张的“游戏育人”主张，也开始逐步走向现实。歌未竟，东方白，希望游戏科学越来越好，希望游戏业界越来越好。

完美通关《黑神话·悟空》：一场始于热爱、终于敬畏的西行史诗
当浮屠塔内杨戬的三尖两刃刀掷出，当天命人拒绝老猴子递来的金箍，当倒叙的回忆里大圣与群妖酣饮的画面渐次褪色为孤身一人，我盯着屏幕陷入了长久的沉默。几十个小时的鏖战，从花果山的晨光到小西天的暮色，从初遇鼠都尉的好奇到击败杨戬的震撼，这场完美通关的旅程，早已超越了“玩游戏”的范畴，更像是一场亲身参与的东方玄幻史诗演绎。《黑神话·悟空》用无可匹敌的文化底蕴、打磨至臻的战斗系统和充满哲思的剧情，为国产3A交上了一份足以载入史册的答卷，即便仍有瑕疵，也难掩其璀璨光芒。
若说普通通关是读懂了“天命人传承”的故事，那完美结局便是揭开了整个世界观的终极真相。游戏科学对《西游记》的改编堪称颠覆性创新，却又始终锚定着原著的精神内核。在游戏的旅程中，我不再是旁观者，而是跟着天命人一起，在碎片化的叙事中拼凑悟空的过往——他并非死于杨戬之手，而是以自我牺牲的方式留存“意”根；那些被我们击败的妖王，并非单纯的反派，而是承载着轮回与苦难的可怜人；杨戬的“磨练”与弥勒佛的“指引”，更让“西行”从“取经赎罪”升华为“自我认知与意志觉醒”的征程。
完美结局的触发过程本身就是一场修行：收集隐藏要素、解锁浮屠塔壁画、迎战杨戬的法天象地。当两大巨人在天地间展开肉搏，举手投足间毁天灭地，那种视觉与情感的双重冲击，是任何CG都无法替代的体验。而最终拒绝金箍的瞬间，更是将主题推向高潮——天命人不是悟空的“替代品”，而是继承其意志的“新生命”，这种“不是复刻，而是延续”的设定，让“齐天大圣”的形象彻底摆脱了传统桎梏，多了几分现代人对“自我价值”的思考。
作为一款动作游戏，《黑神话·悟空》的战斗系统无疑是核心亮点。我从最初被虎先锋虐到怀疑人生，到后来熟练运用识破、退寸、神通连招击败杨戬，这种成长感堪称酣畅淋漓。游戏的BOSS设计堪称“疯狂”，无论是体型庞大的晦月魔君，还是招式精妙的杨戬，每一个BOSS都有独特的攻击逻辑和破局方法，没有重复感可言。尤其是完美结局中的杨戬之战，法天象地的变身特效、多变的攻击模式，以及战斗中穿插的剧情对话，让每场战斗都像一场小型电影。
技能系统的设计也尽显巧思：没有繁杂的天赋树，升级获得的技能点可自由搭配，且支持无代价洗点，让我能大胆尝试棍、枪、拳等不同流派。七十二变不仅是探索工具，更能在战斗中发挥奇效——变身为蜜蜂躲避攻击，变身为石敢当抵御伤害，这种“策略性战斗”让动作玩法更具深度。当然，战斗系统并非完美：重棍蓄力接闪身的操作逻辑略显反人类，部分BOSS“只能修脚”的设计也让人有些憋屈，前期缺乏明确的操作指引，新手只能在反复死亡中积累经验。
大部分的时间都花在了探索上。游戏的地图设计堪称“箱庭艺术的巅峰”，每个章节的地图都相互连通，没有粗暴的加载界面，取而代之的是巧妙的通道衔接与场景过渡。从花果山的奇松怪石到黄风岭的黄沙漫天，从浮屠塔的庄严肃穆到秘境的诡谲奇幻，每一处场景都像是动态的水墨画，细节拉满——石壁上的刻痕、落叶的飘动、妖怪的神态，都彰显着东方美学的独特魅力。
探索的乐趣不仅在于风景，更在于“发现”的惊喜。隐藏的支线任务、强力的武器素材、解锁完美结局的关键道具，都藏在地图的犄角旮旯里。但游戏的引导设计却略显“残酷”：没有明确的任务指示，没有详细的小地图，很多时候只能靠直觉和反复试错。第二章的迷路经历至今让我印象深刻，在错综复杂的路径中来回穿梭，刷怪刷到麻木，一度让人产生弃坑的念头。此外，部分区域的空气墙和光源闪烁问题，也偶尔会打破探索的沉浸感。
抛开“国产3A”的滤镜，《黑神话·悟空》仍有不少值得优化的地方。除了前文提到的引导不足、操作瑕疵，游戏的后期章节明显存在赶工痕迹——第六章的“大盒子”地图空旷乏味，与前期的精细设计形成鲜明对比；部分物品的掉落率低到离谱，我曾为了收集某素材刷了两个多小时，严重影响游玩节奏；优化问题也不容忽视，即便在高性能设备上，部分BOSS战仍会出现卡顿和掉帧现象。
但这些瑕疵，在其巨大的成就面前显得微不足道。游戏科学用一己之力，将东方神话的魅力展现得淋漓尽致：台词中暗藏的文化典故、场景里融入的传统艺术、音乐中传递的民族情感，都让这款游戏成为绝佳的文化输出载体。它不仅证明了国产游戏有能力做出比肩世界顶尖水平的3A作品，更让我们看到了传统文化与现代游戏结合的无限可能。
它不是一款“完美无缺”的游戏，却绝对是一款“足够伟大”的游戏。它用充满哲思的剧情、酣畅淋漓的战斗、美轮美奂的场景，为我们构建了一个既熟悉又陌生的西游世界。完美结局的留白，不仅让“齐天大圣”的故事有了新的延续，更让我们对后续的DLC充满了无限期待——钟馗的故事、天庭的秘密、天命人的未来，这些未解之谜都等待着被揭开。
如果你是动作游戏爱好者，如果你对东方神话充满热爱，如果你愿意花时间去感受一款游戏的深度，那么《黑神话·悟空》绝对值得你入手。它或许会让你在迷路时抓狂，在BOSS战中崩溃，但当你最终解锁完美结局，看到那个继承大圣意志、孤身前行的身影时，你会明白：所有的付出，都值得。

不愧是村里第一个大学生，真的是十分优秀的游戏。《黑神话：悟空》以重走西游为主题，讲述了天命人在冒险途中成长，一步一步继承孙悟空的名号的故事。
[h2] 地图 [/h2]
  《黑神话：悟空》的主要玩法是探索地图与战斗爽。地图主题鲜明，五个章节各不相同，从地图的主题颜色就可以看出。而且每一章的地图都很宏大，第一二章只有一个平面，但是从第三章开始地图就变成有层次的了。但美中不足的是空气墙实在是太别扭了，悬崖那些空气墙用踉跄的动作代替了（而且还不是每个悬崖都有踉跄动作），那平面地图怎么不放写花草水木遮挡一下呢？某些地方看似能去实则不行的感觉太奇怪了。不过瑕不掩瑜。
[h2] 战斗 [/h2]
  战斗机制非常丰富，既有化身又有变身，还有各种天赋点、法术和架势值得琢磨。还有和别的类魂游戏很大的不同的是：黑猴死后不会有惩罚，而且等级归等级，货币归货币，两种变强路径；而且还可以查看地图！这样就可以让玩家在不查攻略、沉浸式体验游戏的情况下还不会迷路了。毕竟游戏最忌讳的就是游戏推进不下去。而且路上的小兵基本没难度，就头目和妖王是有点难度的。可以放心大胆的爽推图。
[h2] 敌人 [/h2]
  敌人的种类也很多，从小兵到头目到妖王，基本不重样的，而且章节与章节之间的妖怪种类还是蛮不一样。
黑猴里还有个猪八戒这个话痨NPC还是蛮有趣的，也让玩家在旅途中多了一点陪伴。而且猪八戒回忆大师兄的过往可能也会引起玩家的共鸣。每一章节后的动画看着也蛮震撼的，感觉有点深度的。还有各种非细节，比如上坡会有轻微减速，筋斗云划过水面会有涟漪等等，可以看出游科是真的认真打磨了的。
[h2] 总结 [/h2]
 最后一章更是惊喜，玩家将降伏孙悟空的各种装备所化成的妖怪，取得孙悟空的所有装备，还能与斗战神佛交手，最后继承孙悟空的名号。这一招一式之间我看到了传承，既是游戏中孙悟空与天命人之间的武艺传承，更是游戏外中华文化的传承。

自2023年到现在，我自认为患上了电子羊尾。我宁愿刷一个周末的短视频，都不愿意打开尘封已久的游戏。
  这对我来说是一件很恐怖的事：一个人连最基础的娱乐都厌倦了，陷入低级娱乐中，何况是生活呢。
  意识到这点后，我采取了补救措施，即每通关或者体验一款游戏，就将它发到朋友圈里，当作是我日常生活的分享，利用人的创造欲、分享欲牵动对游戏的喜爱，同时补救一下我的语文：炼词造句、格式表达。像日记一样，这种方法在之前、现在、以后持续不断的进行。
*分割线*
  上文提到电子羊尾，体现在了《黑神话·悟空》这款游戏里。当时2024年8月20号首发买的，吊起兴打到了第二章一半，后来开学了，在学校里我想着双休、放假在家玩，可是第二次打开却拖延到了2025年8月11日。
  然而，尽管时过一年，我任然被这件艺术作品震撼。鉴于我文学素养不足，此评测会更侧重游戏性。
*分割线*
·谈上手体验·
  中式山林景无疑触动了我基因里欣赏中式美的一部分，唯美。眼睛带来第一感觉。
由于我是用手柄玩的，后来才知道键盘操作的流畅度会比手柄好很多，所以最开始上手打怪的时候没有很明白的理解战斗部分，我觉得这和游戏的引导有关，上来就打天兵天将固然酷炫，我也很理解，但是我们都是第一次玩，而不是有开发者几年的了解钻研经验，缺乏引导的玩家们一上来就给复杂操作的压力，反而适得其反。手感带来第二感觉。
无独有偶，在广智和幽魂的地图上，不得不说，规划是有些许失误的，广智作为主要人物，放在土地庙旁边很远的地方，反而幽魂作为副怪站在了推进剧情的路口处，编排并不合理。
综上，在第一次上手的时候，我是对这个游戏持怀疑态度的，如果画面为主、游戏为辅，那么这个团队更适合做电影。
·谈深入体验·
  伴随着游戏的进行，这份游戏逐渐减少了上述错误。并且一整个游戏背景也慢慢披露出来。要我说最好的章节还得是三四章：第三章整体的美术风格是雪景，自古以来，雪的意象渗透在中国千年文化之中，我在读诗文中雪景的时候，常常会联想出独属中式的一人厚雪景，这款游戏把我的联想摆在了我的眼前，在这方面，他们团队是成功的。
  第四章玩起来挺有意思的，情爱涵盖了整一章的主旨。当时在B站上看纯黑解说，评论区有人问，在整个严肃的游戏主题下插入情爱主题，是否抛开了作品本性？回答我简短的说，肯定不会，因为《西游记》从市井中诞生，难免沾上普通百姓的生活写照和人类的情感，这是其一。神佛部分是最早的人类，包含着人类，是人就有情感，重要的是你如何处理它、压制它，情爱在万物之中，不分神佛，不容苛刻，这是其二。这款游戏将情爱作为单独主题放在作品里，更是侧面表达了人——神——妖三界一题和复杂关系的部分主题。除此之外，里面蜘蛛精的建模挺好看的（这个应该占了大部分原因）。
·谈遗憾·
  玩到第五章时能明显感觉到游戏缩水了，地图远比三四章的小，而且策划似乎想要用恶心的设计来延长玩家的游玩时间，以此显得内容和前面几张一样多和复杂。
  后面了解到，第五章是在时间和经费中挤出来的。我想，如果第五、六章的长度做的和第三章一样，那么我在游玩后也不会有那么大遗憾。
·谈后继·
  幸运的一点是，因为我是《黑神话·悟空》发售一年后才进行的评价，所以已经看见国产单机的生命力了。《黑神话·悟空》最特殊的一点，就是它为中国第一个成熟的3A单机，宣誓证明了国产单机也有好游戏。这一点是很让我尊重的：我并不是彻头彻尾的独立游戏玩家，早些很多年都是在某两家独立游戏的产品下度过的，幸运的是我很早接触了家里的xbox one主机，使得我接触了一些优质的独立游戏里（尽管家里管的严没有多少时间玩，更别说通关）。而不至于沉溺在手游商业式、充值式的不良消费机制里，我感到很幸运。
  在《黑神话·悟空》的成功之后，有很多厂商推出了自己的作品，这是我们希望看到的。而我们不希望看到的是，有人用着这样的路线，打着国产单机的旗号圈钱，用粗制滥造的游戏，散发铜臭味的游戏，没有热爱和打磨的游戏，继续走圈钱为主的商业道路：人民国家为人民，人民游戏为玩家！
  好在一石激起千层浪，最近优秀的国产单机演示视频不少。期待更多国产好游戏的到来！

①美术设计：10.0分。这没什么好说的，满分实至名归。亮眼之处在于每章动画、每章画卷、地图中现实古迹的编排。
②剧情设计：9.0分。此处在网上争议极大，是非曲直，实难以论说，只能斗胆跟评两句。第一章主题是观音妙评；第二章主题是秩序尊卑由天定，这也是中国历史上经久不衰的哲学议题；第三章主题是人心是试探不得的；第四章主题是相爱不一定要在一起；第五章主题是中老年人的身不由己，此点个人感触很深，进入社会之后个人努力确实对事情结果的占比在逐渐下降；第六章主题则是各种意义上的未竟。首先，各章主题分明，很好的阐述了人性中爱与复仇两大核心。其次，各章主题很符合中国传统文学“劝世教人”的核心主旨，章回体结构和半白半文的语言，加上第九艺术的表现力，可以说，黑神话悟空确实是尊重了原著。若就此点论之，各角色人物形象已然不重要，因为后者是具有时代性的，也是历代层垒叠加的结果。综合以上两点，在崇尚个人自由和物质生活从而导致精神生活出现虚无主义倾向的当代，悟空的剧情确实存在一定的教育意义。但是剧情也有问题，即存在一定程度的“中皮西骨”现象。中国传统文学并不主张绝对的善恶，一切权力关系均存在内外两因，套用剧情中的话就是“你那大师兄其实并不圆满”，而不是西方式for freedom的二元对立论。漫天神佛对灵韵的系统性剥削一定是建立在一个不得不的理由之上，否则一个绝对剥削的政治体制绝对难以维持，此处黑神话并没有详加阐述，希望在dlc中游科有所解答。综之，剧情处我个人给9.0分。
③音乐设计：10分。此处分为三块，一是每章主题音乐。不论是《看见》的娓娓道来，还是《三界四洲》的欲壑难填，亦或是《勿听》的百转千回，还是《不由己》的歇斯底里，亦或是《未竟》的饱经沧桑都令人印象深刻。二是游戏背景音乐，首推自然是《敢问路在何方》变调，百转千回，余音绕柱，把“斗罢艰险又出发”展现的淋漓尽致。其他背景音乐也很不错，主要表现在营造战斗氛围的同时还做到了不喧宾夺主。其他同类作品常有boss战多次挑战，导致催人奋进的背景乐变成了无情嘲讽的事实，但黑神话可以说完美避开了这一点。第三块是音效。此处主要指地图背景音效，正如b站up老李聊点什么所说，背景音效真正做到了“大音希声”，即在小雷音寺有寺庙的感觉，在黄花观有道观的感觉。而且现实的背景音效是非常复杂的，有动物声、有风声、有人声，通过音效营造一个真实的环境是很困难的，游科在此处一定是下了极大的功夫。其次是打击音效，此处我个人感觉没什么雷点，但也说不出好赖，就不评价了。
④地图设计：8.5分。其中第一章9.5分，游科在设计小规模的箱庭场景上表现不错。第二章9.0分。第三章8.0分，极乐谷差点给人干出雪盲症。第四章8.0分，阴间下洞。第五章8.0分。第六章5.5分，史中史。综合评价，8.5分。黑神话地图设计中网上最具争议的是便是空气墙，这个问题我个人认为在第二章体现最明显，其出现的根本原因还是黑神话美术太真实，导致在探图时经常出现“我认为此地能去，但是被空气墙阻挡”的情况，此种“为了艺术效果牺牲游戏性”的选择因人而异，不论褒贬皆无可指摘。所有地图中设计最出色的是浮屠塔，如果真的存在十八层地狱，那一定就是浮屠塔的样子。其中石质的转经塔旋转的声音如同磨盘一样在我心中研磨，很有一种身处旋涡无法自拔的无力感，暗合小张太子的“规劝”。加上背景乐中令人牙酸的野兽嘶吼和时不时偷袭的野怪还有几分钟一次的红眼，以及螺旋阶梯的设计，氛围感真的拉满，反正我个人当时被吓得不轻，只想快点逃离。不过一层到四层光线转明以及视野逐渐开阔，确实有柳岸明花的幸存感。另外，此处可以看到游科对于黑神话的设计是非常极端的，他们在商业和价值输出的取舍中偏向了后者，以至于游戏处处体现出了近乎神经质般的偏执。我猜测游科当时的想法就是，这可能是各种意义上第一次也是最后一次说自己想说的机会，不如抓住机会一股脑的全说了，哪怕存在明显工期不足导致的赶工，也要把故事输出出来。
⑤动作设计，9.0分。此处无法详评，因为我对于此处没有什么研究，只能说对我来说没有雷点。不过有一点感受，除了劈棍戳棍和立棍，是不是还缺了一个扫棍之类的对群攻击棍法，总有一种没做完的感觉。还有经过解析，二郎神有70+的变招种类，大圣残躯有40+的变招种类，可以说量堆的相当足，甚至可以说有一点量变引起质变的味道。
⑥人物形象塑造，9.5分。总体而言，各个人物的形象塑造皆很饱满，其中最喜欢的还是大圣，虽然处处没有大圣，但是处处皆是大圣。影神图、章回画卷、游戏其他角色口述各种叙述有真有假，有古有今，真正体现出了老猴所说“你那大师兄并不圆满”。

黑悟空战斗爽快，在打boss这块基本top，但除此之外缺点明显：

1.地图设计。交互性很少，垂直面地图设计除了盘丝洞就没有了，大部分时间都是直来直去，走岔路发现新物件，但地图过大以及没有明显引导，易导致迷路，打击玩家探索欲望。

2.剧情。分类上算动作RPG，但我只能看到动作，而看不到RPG，主线剧情交代给玩家的部分很碎，个人不喜欢阴谋论剧情，但最大的问题在于剧情无法有沉浸感，没有看故事的感觉，也不存在笑点和燃点这种常见的RPG元素，主角是个哑巴，而且剧情里除了打怪，其他没有描述，可以说完全没有塑造，全靠孙悟空这个国民IP补足不足，只能让玩家脑补。我知道黑神话制作很优秀，但既然是RPG，那么讲好故事，可以让玩家有情绪起伏这很重要，不然你大可以说自己是魂类，不需要剧情。既然使用了西游记这个IP，尽管身为中国人很熟悉孙悟空的故事，但我也想看到黑神话中的西游记故事以某种方式复原在黑暗童话中，而不是只单单使用其背景，但内容基本都是原创且写故事能力很差。说实话。这游戏的剧情我直接可以给零分，即便有章节动画也无法弥补其不足，在我看来章节动画并没有很好的起到涵盖本章节剧情的作用，更多的是自由发挥，与游戏剧情直接相关很少，动画的画工可以算艺术级，但传达故事信息这块幼儿园级，有种故作高深的感觉。毕竟是面向大众的作品，通俗地讲故事能力更重要，而不是搁那遮遮掩掩，一副生怕玩家看懂了的样子，简单的说"文青病"太重。

3.个人比较在意的一些小细节：
1）主角走路有飘移感，没有实实在在走路的感觉

It took so long there were times where I thought it was just Vaporware but now finally we can return to Monke. As a European, I have to admit that Chinese mythology is beautiful. Wukong is a very good game but I wouldn't say it's the top echelon of gaming by any means. Combat is great, story is really good (story is amazing if you've read the books), and the graphics are definitely top tier. The reason why its metrics are so high for concurrent player base is almost due to the Chinese audience. It's their folklore and myths reimagined into a video game. It's their historical myth come to life. It resonates deeply with them. It's the same thing with Red Dead Redemption 2 being so popular in the U.S as opposed to China or Korea. It's the U.S historical period. So it resonates with us more than it would them. Doesn't mean they won't enjoy it and the same is with Wukong. It's a really solid game. 

During its peak Steam player count, it had like 2m players… But like 90% of that was again from China. It very much is a 7/8 out of 10 game but a particular group of people made it their identity to champion really hard. It’s probably a bit overhyped but it’s a pretty good game. It’s not fully souls like, in terms of gameplay it’s probably closest to a slightly harder Star Wars Jedi Fallen Order/Survivor or an easier Nioh. It’s not a masterpiece, or groundbreaking, or really a top 20 game ever made or whatever. But it’s based off a super popular ancient Chinese story/myth that’s pretty embedded into the memories of lots of East Asian cultures. The graphics are really nice, it’s fun to play, it’s just one of those games that’s super popular. 

The lore and art is a 10/10 for me, if you're a fan of Xianxias/Journey to the West or Chinese mythos in general, you'll love the game, so many references and Chinese proverbs and every enemy in the game, even the most insignificant one gets a journal with lore of that enemy along with an incredibly well drawn art piece of them in the iconic ancient Chinese art style. Story enjoyment for this game really seems to hinge on your interest in the mythology. A big reason I got hooked on God of War back in the 00s was purely for that reason. This game turns that up to 11. I knew almost absolutely nothing about the legend behind the game, but this story played out incredibly for me. If you feel like youre not getting pulled into the lore/story enough, check out the journal. They really went into great depth with it. The post-chapter vignettes are also very well done and can be downright moving at times. If I hadn't waited until 2024 to play Sex with Hitler 3D, BM: Wukong would have been my favorite game of that year.

Black Myth Wukong is a pretty solid experience and should be celebrated for what it has accomplished, but it does have quite a few flaws that people are overlooking due to the hype surrounding it. I also think a lot of the hype is how it fully embraces Chinese mythology and makes it cool, as someone who’s wife’s boyfriend is half American-East Asian it’s not really something you see embraced and fawned over by Western culture a lot outside of like the usual Kung fu and Samurai stuff. Again it’s kind of like God of War, or Percy Jackson but for Chinese, I mean not fully but something similar. The Chinese market is GIGANTIC so I expected them to react very strongly, however I’m pleasantly surprised to see it embraced/hyped in the West too.

The game is not nearly as difficult as your average souls like outside a handful of bosses and some people do find the combat repetitive, I personally enjoyed it but I can’t deny that you’ll be pretty much doing the same moveset for the entire game. The game is pretty linear so the exploration isn't gonna really be there (there are some secrets here and there though). The bosses are great, this game has more bosses than any game of its size I've ever seen, and I enjoyed fighting every one of them. The boss design and diversity is also top notch, no two bosses are the same, you might find similarities in some of the minibosses but for the most part the game does a good job of making every encounter feel fresh. 

Although pretty basic, the combat played very well for me and it’s not a button masher whatsoever. It’s actually more of a learn the movements and strike when you can game. The total opposite of button masher. Definitely not a soulslike and more of a God of War. But also not as good as God of War more in the Stellar Blade tier of action games. It takes a little while to understand the combat for sure, but one big thing that helped me is to realize that each push of the attack button does one swing of the staff. So if you mash the button three times really quickly, he’ll swing the staff three times, but it can feel like his movements are delayed because by the time you’ve finished mashing attack, he’s still swinging. The better way is to time your button presses to his animations. So if you press the attack button once, wait until that first swing has almost resolved before pressing it again. Once you can feel the rhythm of the attacks, you won’t get caught being hit mid animation as much, and you’ll feel more in control / have a better understanding of the combat. Also, utilizing the different stances and their different power attacks is key.

I honestly can’t recommend it enough if you’re a fan of action games and/or “soulslikes.” It’s gorgeous and fluid with intense combat, incredible art direction and a pretty fun if difficult to follow story until you become more familiar with it. I'm looking forward to the sequel.

[h3]Introduction[/h3]
This game is my first soullike game. I always wanted to challenge myself with one of these games one day, but just never found a story that interested me enough to play through one, until I got this game. I watched the original Journey to the West TV series with my wife about 2 years ago, so I was already familiar with the story before starting the game. This was actually good for me, as I kinda knew what to expect in some parts of the game, though the majority still remained a mystery.

[h3]Bias[/h3]
As a westerner who has always had a deep interest in Chinese culture and history and spent the last 5 years learning Mandarin, a game like this hits a bit different. What I mean is that I automatically will like a large portion of the game just based on my interest in China, just like how any game from Japan gets a lot of positive reviews from people who like Japan, no matter the quality of the game. So when I say this is a great game, keep in mind that I might have a huge bias when I talk about it, I'm aware not everyone will find it fascinating.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
Like I mentioned, this is my first soul-like game, so I don’t have a ton of experience with how a good game in this genre plays, but I can say that it is one of the smoothest triple A titles I have played in maybe more than a decade. The game looks beautiful, it seems to register inputs well and I am yet to crash in the game. I also haven’t encountered any graphical bugs, at least from what I have noticed. It just seems really polished overall. I do have one thing that I really do not like though and that made me almost quit a few times and that is being punished for “button mashing”. I don’t like being punished for how I play or if I’m pressing buttons too fast and I am constantly being punished for it with this anti “button mashing” implementation (that I heard is a feature and not a bug). What it does is that when you activate one of your abilities, a sort of very short animation plays and if you by accident or intentionally hit a button while this animation plays, it can and most of the time in my experience will cancel said ability but still count it as used. So it will give your ability a cooldown and it won’t refund your mana, so it just wasted one of your abilities. This is devastating in this game, since your mana does not recharge during combat and it is often necessary in order for a casual player like myself to beat a boss to have all my abilities have effect. People should be allowed to play how they want in an offline experience like this.

[h3]Story[/h3]
This game is based on the story of Sun Wukong, also known as the Monkey King, but takes place after the time he partook in the Journey to the West. In the show he is following a monk who is traveling to India to collect sacred buddhist scriptures while being accompanied by a few other disciples.

The game happens after these events but takes inspiration from the original tale, with most of the same characters showing up again, though still with the developers own creative twist to it. I personally really liked this approach, since it made the game feel familiar yet new at the same time. While playing I kept guessing what might come next.

[h3]The visuals[/h3]
This game looks really good and runs extremely well considering how good it looks. The character design of the Monkey King feels new but still very familiar to how he looked in the show and the redesigns of all the evil spirits he encounters are terrifying.

[h3]Difficulty[/h3]
Like I said, this was my first soul-like game, and I also don’t really play fighting games, so this was really a new area for me. That said, while it was difficult in the beginning, once you get the hang of it, you can crush some bosses really quickly. I did manage to kill some of them first try, though I also am yet to finish the entire game, so it might get a lot harder near the end.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
My wife gave me this game this summer and it turned out to be really good. I definitely recommend it and especially if you can catch it on sale, though it seems to rarely go down in price, at least by a lot, so if you aren't sure about whether you will like it or not and your cash is tight, wait a few years for it to go down in price.

TL:DR: A tale about a wonderful game that is too loyal to its source material for its own good.
(written and posted after getting all the achievements)

No spoilers here, so feel free to read till the end. 
Also, I'll try to keep it not unreasonably long (kinda hard in this case, tbh)

Where do I start with this one?
I guess, with a good general question. Is it a souls-like? No, I don't think so. While all souls-likes are basically ARPGs, not all ARPGs are souls-like. In my mind it's much closer to something like Darksiders 1 or 2 than to a souls-game.

Now, the review itself.
The game is built on UE5 but is decently well optimized and, what's equally important, it actually looks like a game created on a newer version of an engine, which is not true for some other games on UE5 I played earlier (Lords of the Fallen (2023) and Enotria being good examples).
So, to make it as clear as possible, the game looks very good. Both graphics and design-wise. Random scenery can easily become your new wallpapers. 
Some of the design choices I will not reveal for the sake of leaving this review spoiler-free are wonderful and I adore them. They, together with the OST create an atmosphere of an epic adventure you're a part of.
The gameplay is smooth and pleasant, consisting mostly of numerous bossfights and exploration. Melee combos with a pinch of original magic create a feeling close to a wuxia action. Spectacular and even passionate.
And there's also lots of content to discover, (almost way too) many secrets to hunt for, including locations, bosses and whole questlines.
Also, what's really important for engagement — there's a clear sense of progress in becoming what your character is meant to be plot-wise. You can feel, see and take part the process of forging a legend.

However, it's not a perfect game by any means.
The one main problem it has stems from one fact. It's  too long for what it is.
You have your main character with his unique weapon type. And throughout the game you can find only this weapon type and one slightly different variation of it. The game took me 48 hours to beat once (rest was to get all achievements), including the hardest bosses — considering that I'm quite a seasoned souls-junkie and the game is not hard at all for the most part (it has a certain level of challenge to keep itself engaging, it just doesn't try to make you sweat), but some encounters might take a while for a person less acquainted with ARPGs/Hack-n-slash games or souls-likes.
I absolutely understand the reasoning behind the weapon variety (or more precisely its absence) and a lengthy playtime, and I respect the devs for the bold choice of being so true to the source material, but I also should mention, that by the end of my initial playthrough I was getting bored exactly because of the absence of "build" variety, which should've not been a problem if not for the game being around 10-20 hours longer to beat than similar titles I might compare it to, namely the aforementioned Darksiders games.

Other relatively minor drawbacks:
The game is severely railed. Despite having lots of secrets, it leads you were it wants you to be by an extensive use of invisible walls. Some locations are also pretty linear.
Some achievements — if you're going for 100% — are pretty grindy.
Towards the end of the game signs of lack of time start showing up here and there, you'll notice them especially good in the last chapter
Considering the way the gameplay is built there's no replayability. Not a drawback per se, but should be mentioned, imo.

All that being said, I recommend this game.
If you want an epic, lengthy action-adventure game that tells a good story, not hard  as nails, but with some nice challenges — grab it even for full-prize, you'll not be disappointed.
If you hesitate, sales still exist for this game, albeit they're rather rare and not steep, but if you're reading this while deciding if you want to grab the game with like a 20% discount (like me some time ago) — yes, it is worth it.

Review: Black Myth: Wukong
by Mizaris

Black Myth: Wukong is an absolutely stunning experience from start to finish. Visually, it’s one of those games that constantly makes you stop and stare — the kind that makes you forget what reality even looks like. Every chapter feels carefully crafted, blending myth, atmosphere, and spectacle into something that feels truly cinematic.

The sound design is on another level. With Dolby Atmos enabled, the game feels less like a typical action RPG and more like a full-blown movie experience. Every hit, every spell, every boss encounter is backed by powerful, immersive audio that pulls you straight into the world.

The story follows a very familiar Souls-like structure: cryptic, fragmented, and told through environments rather than exposition. If you’re used to the genre, you’ll feel right at home. The gameplay itself is phenomenal — fast, precise, and incredibly satisfying. For players with Souls-like experience, the difficulty feels fair rather than brutal. It’s challenging, but not overwhelming, with only a handful of bosses really pushing you to your limits.

The chapter-based structure with semi-open worlds works surprisingly well. It keeps the pacing tight while still allowing for exploration. Secret areas are cleverly designed and, best of all, discoverable without relying on guides or the internet. If you stay observant and curious, you’ll find most of them naturally.

All in all, Black Myth: Wukong delivers an exceptional, polished, and unforgettable journey. A beautiful world, incredible audio, strong gameplay, and smart level design come together to create a truly outstanding experience.

- You're stuck relatively with the same light combos throughout the entire game. The heavy combos I feel should be renamed to "situational" combos or something like that, as they're not "heavy" in the same way that most games would classify that term. There are 3 stances that impact a few abilities with the light combos and these "heavy" combos are those abilities. Be aware that even with this, you'll still be using the game 6 attacks through 90% of the game.

- Secrets are just that. Secrets. But some of these secrets are miss-able and are still miss-able in NG+ at the time of this review. E.g. a certain piece of armor during a specific boss fight. You miss it in your first playthrough, and it's gone forever unless you start completely fresh. I have yet to know or hear if it changes in NG++ or beyond.

- Some mechanics are not thoroughly explained in the slightest. Like holding onto the antennas of a giant bug. This is not a spoiler unless you look it up, so don't go looking it up if you're reading this and plan to buy. It'll make sense when you get to the right spot. Anyway, what should be obvious was not initially and believe me when I say this can be very frustrating.

- Game is mostly on rails. I.e. you don't get much exploration outside of the path you're on, with some small exceptions in a couple areas. Don't get me wrong in this as there are a lot of side paths in some of these various areas with some secrets to unlock and collect, but even those are mostly hallways. Would be nice to jump over that small railing down to the area below, but it forces you to walk around the railing and down the stairs.

- Sprinting with L3 should continue sprinting even after jumping. It doesn't. This QoL feature I will nitpick to death because I hated it. You can also hold-sprint with R1/RB to mitigate this but this is unnatural for me personally. When we land on the ground after jumping, it should continue going the same speed as before the jump, unless you're out of stamina.

- In order to understand the full story, you pretty much have to read some outside material. The pacing in this game is a bit chaotic but I feel it'd be less chaotic if you've read the Chinese Novel: Journey to the West. I did not. But after finishing the game, I've been told that I should have the Novel first, and everything would've been much better and much more easily understood. Rip



So again, most of these are minor and some QoL stuff; don't let it deter you. If you're a Souls fan or a Wukong fan then this game should be right up your alley. It's very well made, has some fantastic memorable moments, and I do overall recommend it.

An Unforgiving Masterpiece (But Maybe Not For Everyone)

Let’s get this out of the way first: Black Myth: Wukong is easily one of the most visually stunning and artistically rich games I have ever played. The world, the creature designs, and the sheer spectacle of the boss fights are nothing short of extraordinary. It feels like a true next-gen experience that respects the source material (Journey to the West) with incredible detail.

However, I have to be critical here: this game is NOT for the faint of heart.

While it’s an absolute 10/10 in presentation and combat feel, the difficulty curve is steep. If you are a general gamer expecting a hack-and-slash adventure like the older God of War titles, you are going to hit a wall. There is no difficulty slider, no map to guide you through the confusing level layouts, and some bosses will punish you relentlessly for hours. The invisible walls in exploration can also be frustratingly immersive-breaking.

Pros:
• Combat: Fast, fluid, and incredibly satisfying once you master the stances.
• Visuals: Absolutely drop-dead gorgeous environments and character models.
• Boss Variety: Every boss feels unique, with their own personality and terrifying movesets.

Cons:
• Accessibility: It is punishingly hard for the average player. There are no "easy" modes or assist features to help people just enjoy the story.
• Level Design: Getting lost is easy due to the lack of a mini-map, and the levels—while beautiful—can feel a bit restrictive with invisible barriers.

Verdict:
This is an awesome, extraordinary game that defines what an Action RPG can be, but you need patience and grit to get through it. It’s not a casual romp.
That being said, Game Science has proven they are a top-tier developer. I am already strapped in and hyped for their next project. Bring on Black Myth: Zhong Kui! I can't wait to see how they handle the ghost-catching god next.

Currently in Act 5 of the game, and feel I can leave a review of the gameplay as of now. Short answer is, I love this game. It's graphics are really amazing, even on my lower end system with a RTX 4070 card, It runs very smooth and looks beautiful. I really enjoy the story, and boss battles the most. It seems like there's no end to the amount of bosses in this game, it has ton's and they're almost all unique and creative. The bosses can be somewhat difficult and gives it that Dark Souls kind of boss battles we love and crave more, each and every time we overcome and beat one. Unlike Dark Souls games, there is not a lot of trash mobs nor are they overly difficult, there's plenty of places to rest (shrines). They also don't punish you in this game for dying, so you don't lose your ability to purchase things or level up like you would in Dark Souls. They also allow you to re spec for free and an unlimited amount of times at any and every shrine you rest at. I do enjoy these aspects about this game, it allows trying out new specs and ability's much much much more frequently. Back to bosses they're really fun, and some can be very challenging, even in the first act you'll find some nice challenges, some are optional, some are required to progress. I haven't come across a boss that proved as difficult as Promised Consort Radahn or Malenia in Elden ring, but some have come a little close, such as Scorpion Lord, Yellow Long to name a few. I think my one and only complaint about Black Myth Wukong is how linear the game can be. Unlike most Dark Souls games, you cannot really go of the beaten path and jump up obstacles or terrain etc. to find unique hidden areas or ways to access areas that you normally couldn't. It's pretty much a straight line game and the lock your path on the straight line. There was many areas that appear to look like you could jump right up to reach unexplored terrain but the game wont let you. This makes it kinda hard to find some hidden areas as every now and then they will allow you to go off the beaten path, and a majority of the time you can't. This can cause you to miss items sometimes as you think it's not possible to explore. With all that being said though, this game is really a worthy investment and provides plenty of game play, (50hrs) so far for me and two acts left to go, and it a rewarding gameplay that addicts you after defeating a hard boss, which is what I love about Dark Souls like games.

The main character lacked personality, and there was little narrative depth to keep me invested. The marketing and community buzz emphasized the game’s difficulty, but in practice it was not nearly as challenging as advertised. The game leans heavily on boss encounters, with very few breaks between them, but those fights themselves were not demanding.

The armor system also fell short. There are many armor sets, yet only one or two feel genuinely useful, making the rest feel unnecessary.

The one element I appreciated is the Wukong story itself, but that credit goes to the source material. The narrative foundation already existed, and the game simply adapts it rather than building something truly original.

Black Myth: Wukong looks great, but after a while it gets boring because it’s basically a “boss-fighting first” game. You enter an area, walk a little, then it’s another boss or mini-boss, and the loop repeats so much that it starts feeling like pattern homework instead of an adventure. Exploration exists, but it’s weak—there isn’t enough real discovery or meaningful side content to make the world feel rewarding to roam. Combat is also too animation-heavy. Attacks often feel stiff and “locked in,” so once you commit to a move, reacting or dodging can feel delayed. In big fights with huge bosses and lots of effects, the camera and lock-on can get messy, and sometimes you lose because you can’t clearly see or keep track of the target. The most annoying flaw is navigation: the game doesn’t guide you well, it’s easy to take the wrong path or loop back without realizing, and that turns “exploration” into getting lost. Overall, the visuals and atmosphere are strong, and some bosses look cool, but the gameplay can feel repetitive, the combat isn’t as responsive as it should be, and the poor direction/map design hurts the experience. If you like boss-rush games, you might enjoy it, but if you want exploration and freedom, it can be disappointing.

Let me start off by saying that this game is absolutely gorgeous. The visuals are incredible, the environments are stunning, and the sheer spectacle of the game’s events are breathtaking. This game brings the legend of Sun Wukong and the Journey to the West to life in video game format which is honestly amazing and very impressive. However, this is where the glazing stops.

I 100%’d this game and I’m glad I did just so I know I’ve seen all it has to offer before judging it, and let me tell you this game is absolutely obsessed with itself. I’ve never seen a game so far up its own ass. Everything is a set-piece. Everything has to look cool first and foremost. Gameplay be damned. Reading and reacting to enemy attacks takes a backseat to how cool an enemy attack looks visually. Nothing needs to make sense, nothing needs to be fun, but everything MUST look cool.

The combat loop offers a moderate skill ceiling if you REALLY go out of your way to make it challenging. Almost all of the time it just comes down to dodging and cycling through your cooldowns. In fact, you are heavily incentivised to loop your tools in such a way that the opponent/boss does not get the chance to retaliate. You need go no further than youtube to see what I mean. A lot of the combat showcases consist of stunning the boss > big bonk that takes half his health and knocks him down > boss wakes up into clones that whittle him down for you > by that point he meets his damage threshold to get knocked down again or your stun comes off cooldown and you can just wail on him to finish him off. Resource gaming at its finest.

Boss fights are not signposted at all, so you will randomly stumble into one while exploring. Oh did you use your healing flask and your cooldowns in combat while exploring? That’s too bad, now go into this boss fight disadvantaged and die, only to run back to it once you know it’s here and breeze through it now that you have all your resources.

An overwhelming majority of the bosses will have some kind of attack that forces you into a dodging simulator, i.e. Boss flies up into the sky and becomes invulnerable while unleashing bullet hell on you. It’s very repetitive and obnoxious.

Many of the bosses have a little aura farming mode that they go into where they will just stroll through the arena and stare at you menacingly. I personally enjoyed these and played along by aura farming a little myself, but it feeds further into the design philosophy of: spectacle first, gameplay later.

The game is also perfectly fine with fucking you over and pulling the rug out from under you in service of the spectacle;
[list]
[*]Oh did you get the boss to half health? Here take this scripted sequence/cutscene in which you take forced damage which you will have to heal back once the cutscene is over.
[*]Did you use one of your major cooldowns just before the forced cutscene? That’s really unfortunate, it’s now on cooldown and you wasted it. 
[*]Did the boss have a stun bar or some kind of secondary resource that you were whittling down? Unlucky fam, the boss has now turned into a big invulnerable gold statue and all resources are restored after this awesome choreographed sequence. [*]Was the boss in the middle of a hard stun animation when you reached the health threshold for the scripted sequence? Fuck you sweetie, it’s cutscene time.
[/list]
Unlike most of the clueless casual apes that called this a “souls-like”, I didn’t go into this game expecting it to be a souls-like just because it has bonfire-style checkpoints. I went into the game assuming it would be an action adventure with a focus on melee combat like God of War or Ghost of Tsushima, but just like the casual apes I was mistaken. This is a mostly linear boss rush with a little bit of incidental combat and pretty scenery to break it up.
[olist]
[*]Find the boss fight
[*]Suicide and run back with all your cooldowns ready
[*]Rotate all your cooldowns with just a tiny bit of dodging in between. 
[*]Die because you didn’t coordinate your cooldowns around the scripted sequences and cutscenes.
[*]Run back and demolish the boss easily because now you know when the scripted sequences happen.
[*]Rinse and repeat for 6 chapters[/olist]

I swapped builds constantly, tried weird setups, adjusted for each encounter, and the game happily let me. A few bosses were genuine walls, but the majority go down surprisingly easily considering how dramatic and intimidating their entrances are. The difficulty curve is basically a rollercoaster: struggle on one, steamroll the next ten.

Going for 100% took me about sixty hours, including some material grinding and a bit of NG+ cleanup. The visuals are fantastic and the art direction is consistently strong, even if a few textures look a little unfinished when you get too close. Still, the overall presentation is gorgeous.

There’s real talent behind this, and I’m honestly excited to see what the studio does next.
